name: Simon's Personal Site
body:
### Bio
Simon Halliday is an assistant professor of economics at Smith College in Northampton, MA, USA. Someone works in experimental economics and the microeconomics of development (with a focus on Africa). 

### Teaching
I list my teaching in reverse chronological order
#### Smith College
2014-15: 
* Intermediate Microeconomics (ECO250)
* Economic Development (ECO211) 
* Political Economy of Development in Africa (ECO311)
2013-14: 
* Intermediate Microeconomics (ECO250)
* Economic Development (ECO211) 
* Introductory Microeconomics (ECO150)

#### Royal Holloway, University of London (RHUL) 2012/01-2013/06: 
* Undergraduates: Intermediate Microeconomics, Quantitative Methods of Economics, Institutional Economics & Theory of the Firm, 
* Graduate: Industrial Organization
#### University of Cape Town (UCT) 2006-2012 (*ad hoc*)
* Undergraduate only: Game Theory, Intermediate Microeconomics, Introductory Microeconomics, Intermediate Macroeconomics.

### Research
Under submission: 
* Halliday, Simon 'Don't Take What Isn't Yours: Taking and Punishment in Third-Party Punishment Games'. A very preliminary version is available as an Economic Research Southern Africa working paper, [http://www.econrsa.org/publications/working-papers/rarer-actions-giving-and-taking-third-party-punishment-games](hNumber 211).
* Burns, Justine, Malcolm Keswell and Simon Halliday, 'Risk in the Classroom: An Experiment', a preliminary version is available as [https://ideas.repec.org/p/ldr/wpaper/87.html](SALDRU working paper 87). 

Working papers: 
* To be completed

Published: 
* 'Global Public Goods', 2013, chapter in *Managing the Economy* Santos et al (eds), Open University Press, Milton Keynes, UK

### Projects
* Bowles, Samuel, Duncan Foley and Simon Halliday, forthcoming, *Coordination, Conflict & Competition: A Text In Intermediate Microeconomics* (publisher TBC). Contact me for draft chapters. 
* Halliday, Simon and Jonathan Lafky, 'Reviews as Punishment: An Experiment'. We use a new experimental design to examine behavior of reviewers to see whether they will punish or extort (or encourage bribing by) those they are reviewing. 
* Burdin, Gabriel, Simon Halliday and Fabio Landini, 'Control Aversion and Autonomy'. The project is a replication of Falk and Kosfeld (AER, 2006) paired with variations to suggest the effect of control-aversion may not be as significant as previously found. 

### Collaborators
I have learned a great deal about R and github from @andrewpbray. Kudos to him. 

### Contact
I can be contacted at shalliday{at}smith{dot}edu
